segments.text: I really got tripped out by the thought when I went down to the dining hall of, wow, isn't
this neat? The fathers have provided kosher lepessakh matzot for the Jewish Buddhist meditators.
And it got me sort of thinking about the whole process of history and how things change and
evolve and I mean things that you couldn't even conceive of a few hundred years ago are
now just the norm, you know, and no one even thinks it's strange. I could just imagine,
you know, Saint Ignatius of Loyola or something back in the 16th century, the Counter-Reformation,
if he knew what was going to happen in the next few hundred years, they wouldn't be able
to relate to it at all. So it really, as I say, got me thinking about what in Buddhism
is called anicca or impermanence, how things change. And then I was in my interview room
and you know how I always talk about escaping into, right? You've probably heard me talk
about that, right? It's one of my favorite expressions, like, you know, Buddhist meditation
is escaping into things, not escaping from them. It is truly an escape, it's a transcendence,
but not a denial. It's 180 degrees the opposite direction of denial. So then I see this book
InScape, okay? Right here, it's part of the reading for the fathers and it's by another
father who actually lives in my part of the country. His name is George Maloney, SJ. Most
of you probably know what SJ means, if you don't, it's Societas Jesus, it's the Society
of Jesus, or the Jesuits. He wrote this book called InScape, God at the Heart of Matter,
okay? And it's all on that theme of escaping into things. And what's interesting is he
has written another book, which I think is one of the best introductions to the Christian
contemplative tradition. It's called Prayer of the Heart. And it's actually, even though
he's a Jesuit and a Roman Catholic, the book Prayer of the Heart is primarily about the
Eastern Orthodox tradition of Christian meditation. And as far as I'm concerned, it's there that
the most powerful forms of meditation were practiced. I think most of you probably know
what Eastern Orthodox Christianity is. Actually, we passed on the way out here a Ukrainian
Orthodox church, a really big, beautiful one. I was surprised, like, you know, it's like,
wow. Because you can always tell the Orthodox churches, they have a different kind of cross.
It's got an extra bar on the bottom that's slanted obliquely. So the Orthodox tradition
in Christianity is a form of Catholicism, but it's not centered on Rome. Each local
ethnos or nation has its own independent Orthodox church. So there's a Greek Orthodox, a Russian
Orthodox, a Ukrainian Orthodox, and I think there's like, you know, some of the smaller
countries in that part of the world, Eastern Europe, have their own Orthodox churches.
But historically, Orthodox Christianity is geographically the closest to where Christianity
started, which is the Holy Land. And it grew up in the deserts of Egypt and in Palestine
and those areas. So from a sort of objective, external point of view, we might expect that
the area that was closest to the historical center of Christianity might in some ways
preserve earlier forms or historically deeper forms of the religion. So what's interesting
is that in the various Orthodox traditions, they practiced and continue to practice a
form of spirituality that's remarkably similar to Vipassana meditation. And what I did once
is I took this same man's book, Father Maloney's book, The Prayer of the Heart, and being a
Jesuit, he's an intellectual, so he has all the Greek terminology. You know, there's an
expression, it's not much used much now, but I think it may be from Shakespeare, that the
Greeks have a name for it, the Greeks have a word for it. You may have heard that. Is
it from Shakespeare? Okay. By the way, it may have been Shakespeare that said it, but
I'm sure that the person that originally said it was a Roman. Because you may or may not
be aware, but in the classical tradition of Europe, the Romans more or less copied everything
that was Greek. They looked upon the Greeks as having a true civilization. And a lot of
our so-called Latin words are just translations, literal translations of Greek words. So they
looked upon the Greeks as having very rich and penetrating vocabulary about all aspects
of human experience. So true to form in the West, the Greeks do have a word for it. There
is a copious technical vocabulary of internal exploration in Greek from the Middle Ages,
from the monastic tradition. And Maloney in that book has a lot of their main buzzwords.
So what I did is I went through and I just took all the italicized words, all the foreign
words, the Greek words that he had in, it was a little book like this, and it was a
list of about 20 words. And then right next to them, I put the Pali and Sanskrit equivalents.
And it just lined up one to one. It was just really, really interesting to see the parallelism.
For example, the main practice in Orthodox Christian meditation is to develop something
called isikhiya, that would be written H-E-S-I-C-H-I-A. And in the anglicized pronunciation, it's
given us the word hesychasm. I don't know how many of you have ever heard the word H-E-S-A-C-H-A-S-M.
Is that correct? I think so. Hesychasm. You might look it up in the dictionary. Hesychasm
means the practice of hesychia or quieting the mind. Hesychasm means the aspect of spirituality
that involves calming the mind. In other words, what we call samadhi or shamatha. And a person
that practices that is called a hesychast. H-E-S-A-C-H-A-S-T. You can find these words
in the unabridged English dictionary. I bring it up because I think it's very significant,
it's very important that since we are Westerners, to know that there is a Western analog to
the work that we're doing. You may ask why in that case, since we grew up in the West
and most of us, not all of us, not myself, but probably most of you grew up in the Christian
tradition, why you've never heard of it. Why you're not intimately informed about this
if this was part and parcel of Christianity. And I'll go into that in just a second. But
in any event, hesychia or isychia, if you want to use the modern Greek pronunciation,
hesychasm is the development of states of calm and concentration through practices rather
similar to what we do. And they would sit in certain postures that were stable, just
like ours, yogic type postures. I shouldn't put it in the past tense, it's still done.
There's a place in Greece called Mount Athos where people still do this quite avidly. It's
interesting apropos of what's been going on in the Soviet Union. In the 19th century,
meditation practice, concentrative meditation practice, was quite prevalent in Russia. And
you can read a book about it. I mean prevalent among the householders, the average peasant.
There's a very interesting book called The Way of the Pilgrim, which is about a Russian
peasant in the 19th century who gets initiated into this practice of hesychastic prayer.
And all of the stages and experiences that he goes through in developing this. But what
you had was, you had what they called a starets. I don't know how many of you have any Slavic
background. A starets means an elder, in other words, a spiritual director. And that exactly
corresponds to the Pollywood tera. Tera means an elder or a spiritual director. As you may
or may not know, the Vipassana tradition is derived from the Theravada school of Buddhism.
So you have in the Eastern Orthodox tradition, you have a starets or a guru, an elder, a
thera, a teacher, that directs you along this long path of developing hesychasm or deep
inner quiet. But what's interesting is, not only did they develop the states of calm and
concentration that are the hallmark, of course, of Buddhist meditation, but they did much
more than that. They purified consciousness. And the word for purification is catharsis.
So that's where that has a deep medieval meaning that's similar to what we, our meaning of
visuddhi in Pali or purification. And the way that you did the purification was to go
into the state of hesychia or deep quiet. And then within that state, you would do something
that in Greek is called nepsis, N-E-P-S-I-S, usually translated into English as sober observation.
Sound familiar? Okay. Sober observation. You would observe very carefully. And you would
observe with a quality that the medieval writers in Greek struggled greatly to convey to people.
It was a quality of detachment without being indifferent. And it was, they wrote about
how difficult it was to distinguish this detachment from indifference. Does this sound familiar?
Does this sound like the rap about equanimity? Okay. Well, it is. But the interesting thing
is the Greek word for equanimity has completely shifted in modern English. But in medieval
English, I mean in medieval Greek, in the setting of Christian meditation, the word
for equanimity was apatheia, which has given us the modern English word apathy, which is
very much not the meaning that they would have had. But it's interesting. Whenever you
deal with words, you have to always be aware that a word doesn't have any meaning outside
of the tradition, the context, the historical period, the teacher who's speaking, and the
audience that's being addressed. You have to take all of those things into consideration
if you want to develop a maturity to be able to understand the deep spiritual writings
around the world. There's no such thing as a meaning to samadhi. It's only samadhi used
within a certain tradition at a certain period by a certain teacher speaking to a certain
audience. That's what that word means in that situation. So case in point is the word apathy,
which actually meant equanimity in medieval Christianity. So you would cultivate this
quality of apatheia. You would have a sober observation, a nepsis within a state of deep
ezekia or calm. In other words, it was a kind of vipassana. One of the main things that
they attended to was the sensations in their viscera and in their heart and their guts.
What's interesting is that they would, of course, attend to it with mindfulness and
equanimity, body sensation, especially body sensation. As you probably noticed, this part
of the body tends to have a lot of chakras. There's a lot of emotional stuff that comes
in. So they would watch with equanimity. In order to do it, they would actually sometimes
sort of sit in a yogic posture and turn their head down and actually look at their heart
or look at their abdomen and be very still and just let the sensations bubble up and
observe them. Well, what's interesting is that the more head-oriented monks who tended
to be a little bit more in Western Europe than in the East, they couldn't understand
– this is, we're talking a thousand years ago – some of them couldn't understand
why these people would sit around, why the Greeks, the Eastern Christians, why they would
sit around and observe their body sensations, especially observing their belly and this
kind of stuff. It didn't make any sense. If your experience of religion is all ideas,
beliefs, then you can't understand. It seems, in fact, that a person is miring themselves
in the physical body. And maybe you yourself have wondered. I thought spirituality was
to get me beyond the body. Why am I paying attention, making the body so real? But of
course, the body is where feeling comes up. And our primordial ego blockages, the things
that originally separated us from the Source, came about through holdings around feeling.
The separation from our spiritual source started in infancy. The baby looks at a flame and
the baby is the flame and the flame is God. And since the baby is the flame, it reaches
out to touch itself and has sensation. And then the next time it looks at the flame,
the flame isn't quite so much God and quite so much the baby, because there's a residue.
The pain wasn't fully experienced and it left a residue. And so a sense of separation,
I'm not the flame. Or the baby looks at the wall and is the wall until one day mother
goes behind the wall and the wall gets in the way of the baby and mother. And then the
wall is not the baby anymore. It's a source of fear or a source of limitation or something
solid that you can bang up against or can confine you in some way. So the infant passes
through feeling states and they leave residues. And as a result of that, the primordial oneness
outside the sense of connectedness with everything and inside the connectedness with the spiritual
source becomes alienated. So by paying attention to the body sensations, the blockages are
broken up because whatever residues remain from the past can be broken up by experiencing
the present skillfully. You don't have to do anything else. It'll eventually percolate
up in the present. Also, of course, if you bring enough mindfulness and equanimity to
anything, that thing becomes complete and at the same time becomes empty. It's a completeness
that is an emptiness. It sounds like playing with words. It sounds like a game of the mind
playing with paradoxes. But it's not a game of the mind. It's just the most straightforward
description I could think of. So what we're trying to do is have a complete experience
of the body, which is a true experience of no body. You can sit and be distracted or
lose contact with your somatic afferent, your body input, and it can seem like you don't
have a body, but if I sneak up on you with a pin and stick you, your body is going to
come back really quick with a vengeance. On the other hand, if you have learned how to
have a complete experience of your body, the body is clarified in the two senses of the
English word clear. Something is clear when all the components are distinct, but also
something is clear when it is no longer opaque. Those are the two meanings of the English
word clear. Our language can be very revealing. We're clarifying the body in both senses of
the word. One leads to the other. When all the components, subcomponents and subcomponents
are totally distinct, then the body actually becomes literally transparent. That's an experience
of escaping into the body, which is a true no body experience. It's a realization that
there never was a body. There was only incomplete feeling. That's a mouthful right there, isn't
it? But anyway, when you have that experience, if somebody sneaks up behind you with a pin
and sticks you, all that happens is that there is a beautiful shimmering and rippling of
pure energy. That's inscaping into the body. The same is true for any experience.
This is the central paradox or conundrum of meditation. We have this experience that's
so deeply satisfying and spiritual, and yet at the same time is so empty and insubstantial.
I should say one more thing. The ultimate goal, according to the medieval Christian
concept, at least from the orthodox Catholic point of view, the ultimate goal of the meditation
path is something that in Greek is called theosis, related to the word theos, of course,
meaning God, as in theology. It's funny, when you say it in Greek, it sounds quite reasonable,
theosis. But when you translate it literally into the Latin, it sounds pretty shocking
from a Western point of view, because the Latin translation for theosis would be, of
course, deification, you becoming godlike. And when you say it in Latin, it sounds almost
heretical. When you say it in Greek, it sounds quite reasonable, theosis. It's a godding
process.
By the way, I wonder if anybody knows what the Greek word for meditation is. There is
a generic term for meditation. Very interesting. We talked about semantic shifts, how meanings
of words shift historically. The Greek word for meditation is theoria, t-h-e-o-r-i-a,
which is exactly the English word theory. And what does theory mean, literally in Greek?
It comes from one of the umpteen million Greek words that means to see. There's about a dozen
different words in Greek that mean to see, and this is one of them. So actually, theory
or theoria was something that you saw clearly, something you contemplated or meditated about,
so that you had a clarity of seeing. Now, what does that sound like? Clarity of seeing?
Right? So actually, the Greek translation for vipassana is theoria, is theory, in the
literal sense of it.
In any event, I find it utterly fascinating that people that never heard of Buddhism,
and in fact would have thought that all Buddhists are going to hell, came up with a system so
remarkably parallel. It indicates to me that there's something quite universal going on
here, quite independent of cultures and of dogmatic systems.
So now we come to the interesting question of why it is that if this was part and parcel
for many, many centuries, not peripheral but central to the Western tradition, and we are
Westerners, why didn't we grow up with this stuff? Why do we have to go to Buddhism? And
the reason is because of the various political fracases in the history of Christianity. Because
there's religion and then there's history. And religion is a two-sided sword. I used
to teach comparative religion at college, and I would tell my students that the basic
theme in all study of all religion, in all cultures, in all times, if you want one underlying
theme to look for, to unify the whole picture of human religion in all of its aspects, is
that religion is a two-edged sword. It cuts two ways. One way, it's a vehicle that takes
people beyond their egos. And the other side of religion is that it is a vehicle to affirm
people's egos. It can be used either way. And that's true of every religion, and certainly
that is true of Buddhism. So it's either something that shows you the way beyond your ego, or
it's a tool that you can use to get what you want, to affirm what you already want,
something in service of your ego. Have you noticed that that's true? It's true at every
level of spiritual practice. It's true at the conceptual level. You can use the concepts,
take a concept like no-self, a very great concept. You can use that to realize that
when you're suffering, there's no one suffering, and you can become a free and beautiful human
being based on that concept. But that very same concept can also be used along the lines
of there's no self inside people, so you're not killing anybody when you participate in
imperialistic wars, etc., etc. The same concept, one used to transcend the small self, the
other used to affirm the greed and hatred of political demagogues. That's why Zen, after
World War II, Zen was unpopular for a while in Japan, because it had been used as a philosophical
underpinning for fascism. Does that mean Zen's bad? No. It just means like any other tool,
it can be used or abused. So you may find yourself using and abusing the concepts of
your spiritual path. And then at the level of Samadhi, which is the next level beyond
concept when you develop high concentration power, it's great. You have a vehicle to really
live your life. You also have a super-duper denial mechanism available to you. Is it good
to be able to have a calm mind? Yeah. If we can't, we'll never really be human beings.
On the other hand, the ability to stop your thought is the ability to turn off your conscience.
Can't have one without the other, therefore are you going to misuse that? Yeah. You're
going to, for sure. Everyone does. The issue is a matter of proportion. You may occasionally,
once or twice, abuse that Samadhi power. That's okay, as long as you properly use it a billion
times. But you have to realize you will misuse that tool. At every level, conceptual, at
the level of Samadhi, and then at the level of Prajna, of wisdom, of enlightenment itself.
Even enlightenment can be abused. But again, it's a matter of degree. Enlightenment just
means that you're able to function from the no-self. But that doesn't mean that everything
that you say or do is right. It just means that there's no attachment to the mind and
body as you speak. But because there's a certain power in the presence of a person that's in
the no-self, people will tend to believe just about everything they say. They'll believe
that because that person has liberated their political views, it must be correct because
they're enlightened. Or their sense of humor must be the right kind of sense of humor.
Or if they drink, then that's what enlightened people do, so it's okay to drink, etc., etc.
Anyway, I don't want to get too far off the subject, but religion is a two-edged sword,
and it can be used or abused. And the trick is to accept that fact and recognize in yourself
and in others when the legitimate tool is either being used or being abused. But there's
a phrase in law, I think it goes something like, abusus non tolit usus, or something
like that, which means the fact that something is abused doesn't mean that there's anything
wrong with it per se. Okay, so in any event, religion is a two-edged sword, and when we
look at the history of the Western religions or of Christianity, you can see both of those
edges just as you can if you look at the history of Buddhism. And what happened was that certain
